2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eby: Oege Dijk\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThis package makes it convenient to quickly deploy a dashboard web app\nthat explains the workings of a (scikit-learn compatible) machine\nlearning model. The dashboard provides interactive plots on model performance,\nfeature importances, feature contributions to individual predictions,\n\"what if\" analysis,\npartial dependence plots, SHAP (interaction) values, visualization of individual\ndecision trees, etc.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eYou can also interactively explore components of the dashboard in a\nnotebook/colab environment (or just launch a dashboard straight from there).\nOr design a dashboard with your own \u003ca href=\"https://explainerdashboard.readthedocs.io/en/latest/buildcustom.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ecustom layout\u003c/a\u003e\nand explanations (thanks to the modular design of the library). And you can combine multiple dashboards into\na single \u003ca href=\"https://explainerdashboard.readthedocs.io/en/latest/hub.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eExplainerHub\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eDashboards can be exported to static html directly from a running dashboard, or\nprogrammatically as an artifact as part of an automated CI/CD deployment process.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eExamples deployed at: \u003ca href=\"http://titanicexplainer.herokuapp.com\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003etitanicexplainer.herokuapp.com\u003c/a\u003e,\ndetailed documentation at \u003ca href=\"http://explainerdashboard.readthedocs.io\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eexplainerdashboard.readthedocs.io\u003c/a\u003e,\nexample notebook on how to launch dashboard for different models \u003ca href=\"/oegedijk/explainerdashboard/blob/master/notebooks/dashboard_examples.ipynb\"\u003ehere\u003c/a\u003e, and an example notebook on how to interact with the explainer object \u003ca href=\"/oegedijk/explainerdashboard/blob/master/notebooks/explainer_examples.ipynb\"\u003ehere\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eWorks with \u003ccode\u003escikit-learn\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003exgboost\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003ecatboost\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003elightgbm\u003c/code\u003e, and \u003ccode\u003eskorch\u003c/code\u003e\n(sklearn wrapper for tabular PyTorch models) and others.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eBackground\u003c/h2\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-background\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Background\" href=\"#background\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIn a lot of organizations, especially governmental, but with the GDPR also increasingly in private sector, it is becoming more and more important to be able to explain the inner workings of your machine learning algorithms. Customers have to some extent a right to an explanation why they received a certain prediction, and more and more internal and external regulators require it. With recent innovations in explainable AI (e.g. SHAP values) the old black box trope is no longer valid, but it can still take quite a bit of data wrangling and plot manipulation to get the explanations out of a model. This library aims to make this easy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe goal is manyfold:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eMake it easy for data scientists to quickly inspect the workings and performance of their model in a few lines of code\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eMake it possible for non data scientist stakeholders such as managers, directors, internal and external watchdogs to interactively inspect the inner workings of the model without having to depend on a data scientist to generate every plot and table\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eMake it easy to build an application that explains individual predictions of your model for customers that ask for an explanation\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eExplain the inner workings of the model to the people working (human-in-the-loop) with it so that they gain understanding what the model does and doesn't do. This is important so that they can gain an intuition for when the model is likely missing information and may have to be overruled.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe library includes:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eShap values\u003c/em\u003e (i.e. what is the contributions of each feature to each individual prediction?)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003ePermutation importances\u003c/em\u003e (how much does the model metric deteriorate when you shuffle a feature?)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003ePartial dependence plots\u003c/em\u003e (how does the model prediction change when you vary a single feature?\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eShap interaction values\u003c/em\u003e (decompose the shap value into a direct effect an interaction effects)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eFor Random Forests and xgboost models: visualisation of individual decision trees\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePlus for classifiers: precision plots, confusion matrix, ROC AUC plot, PR AUC plot, etc\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eFor regression models: goodness-of-fit plots, residual plots, etc.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe library is designed to be modular so that it should be easy to design your own interactive dashboards with plotly dash, with most of the work of calculating and formatting data, and rendering plots and tables handled by \u003ccode\u003eexplainerdashboard\u003c/code\u003e, so that you can focus on the layout\nand project specific textual explanations. (i.e. design it so that it will be interpretable for business users in your organization, not just data scientists)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAlternatively, there is a built-in standard dashboard with pre-built tabs (that you can switch off individually)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eExamples of use\u003c/h2\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-examples-of-use\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Examples of use\" href=\"#examples-of-use\"\u003e\u003csvg 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eFitting a model, building the explainer object, building the dashboard, and then running it can be as simple as:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-python notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"ExplainerDashboard(ClassifierExplainer(RandomForestClassifier().fit(X_train, y_train), X_test, y_test)).run()\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-v\"\u003eExplainerDashboard\u003c/span\u003e(\u003cspan class=\"pl-v\"\u003eClassifierExplainer\u003c/span\u003e(\u003cspan class=\"pl-v\"\u003eRandomForestClassifier\u003c/span\u003e().\u003cspan class=\"pl-en\"\u003efit\u003c/span\u003e(\u003cspan class=\"pl-v\"\u003eX_train\u003c/span\u003e, \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003ey_train\u003c/span\u003e), \u003cspan class=\"pl-v\"\u003eX_test\u003c/span\u003e, \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003ey_test\u003c/span\u003e)).\u003cspan class=\"pl-en\"\u003erun\u003c/span\u003e()\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eBelow a multi-line example, adding a few extra parameters.\nYou can group onehot encoded categorical variables together using the \u003ccode\u003ecats\u003c/code\u003e\nparameter. You can either pass a dict specifying a list of onehot cols per\ncategorical feature, or if you encode using e.g.\n\u003ccode\u003epd.get_dummies(df.Name, prefix=['Name'])\u003c/code\u003e (resulting in column names \u003ccode\u003e'Name_Adam', 'Name_Bob'\u003c/code\u003e)\nyou can simply pass the prefix \u003ccode\u003e'Name'\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-python notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestClassifier\nfrom explainerdashboard import ClassifierExplainer, ExplainerDashboard\nfrom explainerdashboard.datasets import titanic_survive, titanic_names\n\nfeature_descriptions = {\n    \u0026quot;Sex\u0026quot;: \u0026quot;Gender of passenger\u0026quot;,\n    \u0026quot;Gender\u0026quot;: \u0026quot;Gender of passenger\u0026quot;,\n    \u0026quot;Deck\u0026quot;: \u0026quot;The deck the passenger had their cabin on\u0026quot;,\n    \u0026quot;PassengerClass\u0026quot;: \u0026quot;The class of the ticket: 1st, 2nd or 3rd class\u0026quot;,\n    \u0026quot;Fare\u0026quot;: \u0026quot;The amount of money people paid\u0026quot;, \n    \u0026quot;Embarked\u0026quot;: \u0026quot;the port where the passenger boarded the Titanic. Either Southampton, Cherbourg or Queenstown\u0026quot;,\n    \u0026quot;Age\u0026quot;: \u0026quot;Age of the passenger\u0026quot;,\n    \u0026quot;No_of_siblings_plus_spouses_on_board\u0026quot;: \u0026quot;The sum of the number of siblings plus the number of spouses on board\u0026quot;,\n    \u0026quot;No_of_parents_plus_children_on_board\u0026quot; : \u0026quot;The sum of the number of parents plus the number of children on board\u0026quot;,\n}\n\nX_train, y_train, X_test, y_test = titanic_survive()\ntrain_names, test_names = titanic_names()\nmodel = RandomForestClassifier(n_estimators=50, max_depth=5)\nmodel.fit(X_train, y_train)\n\nexplainer = ClassifierExplainer(model, X_test, y_test, \n                                cats=['Deck', 'Embarked',\n                                    {'Gender': ['Sex_male', 'Sex_female', 'Sex_nan']}],\n                                cats_notencoded={'Embarked': 'Stowaway'}, # defaults to 'NOT_ENCODED'\n                                descriptions=feature_descriptions, # adds a table and hover labels to dashboard\n                                labels=['Not survived', 'Survived'], # defaults to ['0', '1', etc]\n                                idxs = test_names, # defaults to X.index\n                                index_name = \u0026quot;Passenger\u0026quot;, # defaults to X.index.name\n                                target = \u0026quot;Survival\u0026quot;, # defaults to y.name\n                                )\n\ndb = ExplainerDashboard(explainer, \n                        title=\u0026quot;Titanic Explainer\u0026quot;, # defaults to \u0026quot;Model Explainer\u0026quot;\n                        shap_interaction=False, # you can switch off tabs with bools\n                        )\ndb.run(port=8050)\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003efrom\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003esklearn\u003c/span\u003e.\u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003eensemble\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003eimport\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-v\"\u003eRandomForestClassifier\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003efrom\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003eexplainerdashboard\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003eimport\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-v\"\u003eClassifierExplainer\u003c/span\u003e, \u003cspan class=\"pl-v\"\u003eExplainerDashboard\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003efrom\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003eexplainerdashboard\u003c/span\u003e.\u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003edatasets\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003eimport\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003etitanic_survive\u003c/span\u003e, \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003etitanic_names\u003c/span\u003e\n\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003efeature_descriptions\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e=\u003c/span\u003e {\n    \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\"Sex\"\u003c/span\u003e: \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\"Gender of passenger\"\u003c/span\u003e,\n    \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\"Gender\"\u003c/span\u003e: \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\"Gender of passenger\"\u003c/span\u003e,\n    \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\"Deck\"\u003c/span\u003e: \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\"The deck the passenger had their cabin on\"\u003c/span\u003e,\n    \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\"PassengerClass\"\u003c/span\u003e: \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\"The class of the ticket: 1st, 2nd or 3rd class\"\u003c/span\u003e,\n    \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\"Fare\"\u003c/span\u003e: \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\"The amount of money people paid\"\u003c/span\u003e, \n    \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\"Embarked\"\u003c/span\u003e: \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\"the port where the passenger boarded the Titanic. Either Southampton, Cherbourg or Queenstown\"\u003c/span\u003e,\n    \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\"Age\"\u003c/span\u003e: \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\"Age of the passenger\"\u003c/span\u003e,\n    \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\"No_of_siblings_plus_spouses_on_board\"\u003c/span\u003e: \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\"The sum of the number of siblings plus the number of spouses on board\"\u003c/span\u003e,\n    \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\"No_of_parents_plus_children_on_board\"\u003c/span\u003e : \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\"The sum of the number of class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e=\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e50\u003c/span\u003e, \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003emax_depth\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e=\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e5\u003c/span\u003e)\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003emodel\u003c/span\u003e.\u003cspan class=\"pl-en\"\u003efit\u003c/span\u003e(\u003cspan class=\"pl-v\"\u003eX_train\u003c/span\u003e, \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003ey_train\u003c/span\u003e)\n\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003eexplainer\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e=\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-v\"\u003eClassifierExplainer\u003c/span\u003e(\u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003emodel\u003c/span\u003e, \u003cspan class=\"pl-v\"\u003eX_test\u003c/span\u003e, \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003ey_test\u003c/span\u003e, \n dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eDealing with slow calculations\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-dealing-with-slow-calculations\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Dealing with slow calculations\" href=\"#dealing-with-slow-calculations\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eSome of the calculations for the dashboard such as calculating SHAP (interaction) values\nand permutation importances can be slow for large datasets and complicated models.\nThere are a few tricks to make this less painful:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSwitching off the interactions tab (\u003ccode\u003eshap_interaction=False\u003c/code\u003e) and disabling\npermutation importances (\u003ccode\u003eno_permutations=True\u003c/code\u003e). Especially SHAP interaction\nvalues can be very slow to calculate, and often are not needed for analysis.\nFor permutation importances you can set the \u003ccode\u003en_jobs\u003c/code\u003e parameter to speed up\nthe calculation in parallel.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCalculate approximate shap values. You can pass approximate=True as a shap parameter by\npassing \u003ccode\u003eshap_kwargs=dict(approximate=True)\u003c/code\u003e to the explainer initialization.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eStoring the explainer. The calculated properties are only calculated once\nfor each instance, however each time when you instantiate a new explainer\ninstance they will have to be recalculated. You can store them with\n\u003ccode\u003eexplainer.dump(\"explainer.joblib\")\u003c/code\u003e and load with e.g.\n\u003ccode\u003eClassifierExplainer.from_file(\"explainer.joblib\")\u003c/code\u003e. All calculated properties\nare stored along with the explainer.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUsing a smaller (test) dataset, or using smaller decision trees.\nTreeShap computational complexity is \u003ccode\u003eO(TLD^2)\u003c/code\u003e, where \u003ccode\u003eT\u003c/code\u003e is the\nnumber of trees, \u003ccode\u003eL\u003c/code\u003e is the maximum number of leaves in any tree and\n\u003ccode\u003eD\u003c/code\u003e the maximal depth of any tree. So reducing the number of leaves or average\ndepth in the decision tree can really speed up SHAP calculations.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePre-computing shap values. Perhaps you already have calculated the shap values\nsomewhere, or you can calculate them off on a giant cluster somewhere, or\nyour model supports \u003ca href=\"https://github.com/rapidsai/gputreeshap\"\u003eGPU generated shap values\u003c/a\u003e.\nYou can simply add these pre-calculated shap values to the explainer\nwith \u003ccode\u003eexplainer.set_shap_values()\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003eexplainer.set_shap_interaction_values()\u003c/code\u003e methods.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePlotting only a random sample of points. When you have a lots of observations,\nsimply rendering the plots may get slow as well. You can pass the \u003ccode\u003eplot_sample\u003c/code\u003e\nparameter to render a (different each time) random sample of observations\nfor the various scatter plots in the dashboard. E.g.:\n\u003ccode\u003eExplainerDashboard(explainer, plot_sample=1000).run()\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eLaunching from within a notebook\u003c/h2\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-launching-from-within-a-notebook\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Launching from within a notebook\" href=\"#launching-from-within-a-notebook\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eWhen working inside Jupyter or Google Colab you can use\n\u003ccode\u003eExplainerDashboard(mode='inline')\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003eExplainerDashboard(mode='external')\u003c/code\u003e or\n\u003ccode\u003eExplainerDashboard(mode='jupyterlab')\u003c/code\u003e, to run the dashboard inline in the notebook,\nor in a seperate tab but keep the notebook interactive. (\u003ccode\u003edb.run(mode='inline')\u003c/code\u003e\nnow also works)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThere is also a specific interface for quickly displaying interactive components\ninline in your notebook: \u003ccode\u003eInlineExplainer()\u003c/code\u003e. For example you can use\n\u003ccode\u003eInlineExplainer(explainer).shap.dependence()\u003c/code\u003e to display the shap dependence\ncomponent interactively in your notebook output cell.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eCommand line tool\u003c/h2\u003e\u003ca \u003ccode\u003eexplainer.dump(\"explainer.joblib\")\u003c/code\u003e\nand then run them from the command-line:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate explainer.joblib\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eOr store the full configuration of a dashboard to \u003ccode\u003e.yaml\u003c/code\u003e with e.g.\n\u003ccode\u003edashboard.to_yaml(\"dashboard.yaml\", explainerfile=\"explainer.joblib\", dump_explainer=True)\u003c/code\u003e and run it with:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ explainerdashboard run dashboard.yaml\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e$ explainerdashboard run dashboard.yaml\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eYou can also build explainers from the commandline with \u003ccode\u003eexplainerdashboard build\u003c/code\u003e.\nSee \u003ca href=\"https://explainerdashboard.readthedocs.io/en/latest/cli.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eexplainerdashboard CLI documentation\u003c/a\u003e\nfor your own custom \u003ca href=\"https://dash.plotly.com/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003edash\u003c/a\u003e dashboards\naround them.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eBy using the built-in \u003ccode\u003eExplainerComponent\u003c/code\u003e class it is easy to build your\nown layouts, with just a bare minimum of knowledge of HTML and \u003ca href=\"https://dash-bootstrap-components.opensource.faculty.ai/docs/quickstart/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ebootstrap\u003c/a\u003e. For\nexample if you only wanted to display the \u003ccode\u003eConfusionMatrixComponent\u003c/code\u003e and\n\u003ccode\u003eShapContributionsGraphComponent\u003c/code\u003e, but hide\na few toggles:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-python notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"from explainerdashboard.custom import *\n\nclass CustomDashboard(ExplainerComponent):\n    def __init__(self, explainer, name=None):\n        super().__init__(explainer, title=\u0026quot;Custom Dashboard\u0026quot;)\n        self.confusion = ConfusionMatrixComponent(explainer, name=self.name+\u0026quot;cm\u0026quot;,\n                            hide_selector=True, hide_percentage=True,\n                            cutoff=0.75)\n        self.contrib = ShapContributionsGraphComponent(explainer, name=self.name+\u0026quot;contrib\u0026quot;,\n                            hide_selector=True, hide_cats=True, \n                            hide_depth=True, hide_sort=True,\n                            index='Rugg, Miss. Emily')\n        \n    def layout(self):\n        return dbc.Container([\n            dbc.Row([\n                dbc.Col([\n                    html.H1(\u0026quot;Custom Demonstration:\u0026quot;),\n                    html.H3(\u0026quot;How to build your own layout using ExplainerComponents.\u0026quot;)\n                ])\n            ]),\n            dbc.Row([\n                dbc.Col([\n                    self.confusion.layout(),\n                ]),\n                dbc.Col([\n                    self.contrib.layout(),\n                ])\n            ])\n        ])\n\ndb = ExplainerDashboard(explainer, CustomDashboard, hide_header=True).run()\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003efrom\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eWhen you deploy a dashboard with a dataset with a large number of rows (\u003ccode\u003en\u003c/code\u003e) and columns (\u003ccode\u003em\u003c/code\u003e),\nthe memory usage of the dashboard can be substantial. You can check the (approximate)\nmemory usage with \u003ccode\u003eexplainer.memory_usage()\u003c/code\u003e. (as a side note: if you have lots\nof rows, you probably want to set the \u003ccode\u003eplot_sample\u003c/code\u003e parameter as well)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIn order to reduce the memory footprint there are a number of things you can do:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eNot including shap interaction tab: shap interaction values are shape (\u003ccode\u003en*m*m\u003c/code\u003e),\nso can take a subtantial amount of memory.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eSetting a lower precision. By default shap values are stored as \u003ccode\u003e'float64'\u003c/code\u003e,\nbut you can store them as \u003ccode\u003e'float32'\u003c/code\u003e instead and save half the space:\n\u003ccode\u003eClassifierExplainer(model, X_test, y_test, precision='float32')\u003c/code\u003e. You\ncan also set a lower precision on your \u003ccode\u003eX_test\u003c/code\u003e dataset yourself of course.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eFor multi class classifier, by default \u003ccode\u003eClassifierExplainer\u003c/code\u003e calculates\nshap values for all classes. If you're only interested in a single class\nyou can drop the other shap values: \u003ccode\u003eexplainer.keep_shap_pos_label_only(pos_label)\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eStoring data externally. You can for example only store a subset of 10.000 rows in\nthe explainer itself (enough to generate importance and dependence plots),\nand store the rest of your millions of rows of input data in an external file\nor database:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ewith \u003ccode\u003eexplainer.set_X_row_func()\u003c/code\u003e you can set a function that takes\nan \u003ccode\u003eindex\u003c/code\u003e as argument and returns a single row dataframe with model\ncompatible input data for that index. This function can include a query\nto a database or fileread.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ewith \u003ccode\u003eexplainer.set_y_func()\u003c/code\u003e you can set a function that takes\nand \u003ccode\u003eindex\u003c/code\u003e as argument and returns the observed outcome \u003ccode\u003ey\u003c/code\u003e for\nthat index.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ewith \u003ccode\u003eexplainer.set_index_list_func()\u003c/code\u003e you can set a function\nthat returns a list of available indexes that can be queried. Only gets\ncalled upon start of the dashboard.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIf you have a very large number of indexes and the user is able to look\nthem up elsewhere, you can also replace the index dropdowns with a simple free\ntext field with \u003ccode\u003eindex_dropdown=False\u003c/code\u003e. Only valid indexes (i.e. in the\n\u003ccode\u003eget_index_list()\u003c/code\u003e list) get propagated\nto other components by default, but this can be overriden with \u003ccode\u003eindex_check=False\u003c/code\u003e.\nInstead of an \u003ccode\u003eindex_list_func\u003c/code\u003e you can also set an\n\u003ccode\u003eexplainer.set_index_check_func(func)\u003c/code\u003e which should return a bool whether\nthe \u003ccode\u003eindex\u003c/code\u003e exists or not.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eImportant: these function can be called multiple times by multiple independent\ncomponents, so probably best to implement some kind of caching functionality.\nThe functions you pass can be also methods, so you have access to all of the\ninternals of the explainer.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">by: Oege Dijk</p><p dir="auto">This package makes it convenient to quickly deploy a dashboard web appthat explains the workings of a (scikit-learn compatible) machinelearning model. The dashboard provides interactive plots on model performance,feature importances, feature contributions to individual predictions,"what if" analysis,partial dependence plots, SHAP (interaction) values, visualization of individualdecision trees, etc.</p><p dir="auto">You can also interactively explore components of the dashboard in anotebook/colab environment (or just launch a dashboard straight from there).Or design a dashboard with your own <a href="https://explainerdashboard.readthedocs.io/en/latest/buildcustom.html" rel="nofollow">custom layout</a>and explanations (thanks to the modular design of the library). And you can combine multiple dashboards intoa single <a href="https://explainerdashboard.readthedocs.io/en/latest/hub.html" rel="nofollow">ExplainerHub</a>.</p><p dir="auto">Dashboards can be exported to static html directly from a running dashboard, orprogrammatically as an artifact as part of an automated CI/CD deployment process.</p><p dir="auto">Examples deployed at: <a href="http://titanicexplainer.herokuapp.com" rel="nofollow">titanicexplainer.herokuapp.com</a>,detailed documentation at <a href="http://explainerdashboard.readthedocs.io" rel="nofollow">explainerdashboard.readthedocs.io</a>,example notebook on how to launch dashboard for different models <a href="/oegedijk/explainerdashboard/blob/master/notebooks/dashboard_examples.ipynb">here</a>, and an example notebook on how to interact with the explainer object <a href="/oegedijk/explainerdashboard/blob/master/notebooks/explainer_examples.ipynb">here</a>.</p><p dir="auto">Works with <code>scikit-learn</code>, <code>xgboost</code>, <code>catboost</code>, <code>lightgbm</code>, and <code>skorch</code>(sklearn wrapper for tabular PyTorch models) and others.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Installation</h2><a id="user-content-installation" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Installation" href="#installation"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" href="http://titanicexplainer.herokuapp.com" rel="nofollow">titanicexplainer.herokuapp.com</a>)</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Background</h2><a id="user-content-background" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Background" href="#background"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">In a lot of organizations, especially governmental, but with the GDPR also increasingly in private sector, it is becoming more and more important to be able to explain the inner workings of your machine learning algorithms. Customers have to some extent a right to an explanation why they received a certain prediction, and more and more internal and external regulators require it. With recent innovations in explainable AI (e.g. SHAP values) the old black box trope is no longer valid, but it can still take quite a bit of data wrangling and plot manipulation to get the explanations out of a model. This library aims to make this easy.</p><p dir="auto">The goal is manyfold:</p><ul dir="auto"><li>Make it easy for data scientists to quickly inspect the workings and performance of their model in a few lines of code</li><li>Make it possible for non data scientist stakeholders such as managers, directors, internal and external watchdogs to interactively inspect the inner workings of the model without having to depend on a data scientist to generate every plot and table</li><li>Make it easy to build an application that explains individual predictions of your model for customers that ask for an explanation</li><li>Explain the inner workings of the model to the people working (human-in-the-loop) with it so that they gain understanding what the model does and doesn't do. This is important so that they can gain an intuition for when the model is likely missing information and may have to be overruled.</li></ul><p dir="auto">The library includes:</p><ul dir="auto"><li><em>Shap values</em> (i.e. what is the contributions of each feature to each individual prediction?)</li><li><em>Permutation importances</em> (how much does the model metric deteriorate when you shuffle a feature?)</li><li><em>Partial dependence plots</em> (how does the model prediction change when you vary a single feature?</li><li><em>Shap interaction values</em> (decompose the shap value into a direct effect an interaction effects)</li><li>For Random Forests and xgboost models: visualisation of individual decision trees</li><li>Plus for classifiers: precision plots, confusion matrix, ROC AUC plot, PR AUC plot, etc</li><li>For regression models: goodness-of-fit plots, residual plots, etc.</li></ul><p dir="auto">The library is designed to be modular so that it should be easy to design your own interactive dashboards with plotly dash, with most of the work of calculating and formatting data, and rendering plots and tables handled by <code>explainerdashboard</code>, so that you can focus on the layoutand project specific textual explanations. (i.e. design it so that it will be interpretable for business users in your organization, not just data scientists)</p><p dir="auto">Alternatively, there is a built-in standard dashboard with pre-built tabs (that you can switch off individually)</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Examples of use</h2><a id="user-content-examples-of-use" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Examples of use" href="#examples-of-use"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">Fitting a model, building the explainer object, building the dashboard, and then running it can be as simple as:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-python notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="ExplainerDashboard(ClassifierExplainer(RandomForestClassifier().fit(X_train, y_train), X_test, y_test)).run()"><pre><span class="pl-v">ExplainerDashboard</span>(<span class="pl-v">ClassifierExplainer</span>(<span class="pl-v">RandomForestClassifier</span>().<span class="pl-en">fit</span>(<span class="pl-v">X_train</span>, <span class="pl-s1">y_train</span>), <span class="pl-v">X_test</span>, <span class="pl-s1">y_test</span>)).<span class="pl-en">run</span>()</pre></div><p dir="auto">Below a multi-line example, adding a few extra parameters.You can group onehot encoded categorical variables together using the <code>cats</code>parameter. You can either pass a dict specifying a list of onehot cols percategorical feature, or if you encode using e.g.<code>pd.get_dummies(df.Name, prefix=['Name'])</code> (resulting in column names <code>'Name_Adam', 'Name_Bob'</code>)you can simply pass the prefix <code>'Name'</code>:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-python notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestClassifierfrom explainerdashboard import ClassifierExplainer, ExplainerDashboardfrom explainerdashboard.datasets import titanic_survive, titanic_namesfeature_descriptions = {    "Sex": "Gender of passenger",    "Gender": "Gender of passenger",    "Deck": "The deck the passenger had their cabin on",    "PassengerClass": "The class of the ticket: 1st, 2nd or 3rd class",    "Fare": "The amount of money people paid",     "Embarked": "the port where the passenger boarded the Titanic. Either Southampton, Cherbourg or Queenstown",    "Age": "Age of the passenger",    "No_of_siblings_plus_spouses_on_board": "The sum of the number of siblings plus the number of spouses on board",    "No_of_parents_plus_children_on_board" : "The sum of the number of parents plus the number of children on board",}X_train, y_train, X_test, y_test = titanic_survive()train_names, test_names = titanic_names()model = RandomForestClassifier(n_estimators=50, max_depth=5)model.fit(X_train, y_train)explainer = ClassifierExplainer(model, X_test, y_test,                                 cats=['Deck', 'Embarked',                                    {'Gender': ['Sex_male', 'Sex_female', 'Sex_nan']}],                                cats_notencoded={'Embarked': 'Stowaway'}, # defaults to 'NOT_ENCODED'                                descriptions=feature_descriptions, # adds a table and hover labels to dashboard                                labels=['Not survived', 'Survived'], # defaults to ['0', '1', etc]                                idxs = test_names, # defaults to X.index                                index_name = "Passenger", # defaults to X.index.name                                target = "Survival", # defaults to y.name                                )db = ExplainerDashboard(explainer,                         title="Titanic Explainer", # defaults to "Model Explainer"                        shap_interaction=False, # you can switch off tabs with bools                        )db.run(port=8050)"><pre><span class="pl-k">from</span> <span class="pl-s1">sklearn</span>.<span class="pl-s1">ensemble</span> <span class="pl-k">import</span> <span class="pl-v">RandomForestClassifier</span><span class="pl-k">from</span> <span class="pl-s1">explainerdashboard</span> <span class="pl-k">import</span> <span class="pl-v">ClassifierExplainer</span>, <span class="pl-v">ExplainerDashboard</span><span class="pl-k">from</span> <span class="pl-s1">explainerdashboard</span>.<span class="pl-s1">datasets</span> <span class="pl-k">import</span> <span class="pl-s1">titanic_survive</span>, <span class="pl-s1">titanic_names</span><span class="pl-s1">feature_descriptions</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> {    <span class="pl-s">"Sex"</span>: <span class="pl-s">"Gender of passenger"</span>,    <span class="pl-s">"Gender"</span>: <span class="pl-s">"Gender of passenger"</span>,    <span class="pl-s">"Deck"</span>: <span class="pl-s">"The deck the passenger had their cabin on"</span>,    <span class="pl-s">"PassengerClass"</span>: <span class="pl-s">"The class of the ticket: 1st, 2nd or 3rd class"</span>,    <span class="pl-s">"Fare"</span>: <span class="pl-s">"The amount of money people paid"</span>,     <span class="pl-s">"Embarked"</span>: <span class="pl-s">"the port where the passenger boarded the Titanic. Either Southampton, Cherbourg or Queenstown"</span>,    <span class="pl-s">"Age"</span>: <span class="pl-s">"Age of the passenger"</span>,    <span class="pl-s">"No_of_siblings_plus_spouses_on_board"</span>: <span class="pl-s">"The sum of the number of siblings plus the number of spouses on board"</span>,    <span class="pl-s">"No_of_parents_plus_children_on_board"</span> : <span class="pl-s">"The sum of the number of parents plus the number of children on board"</span>,}<span class="pl-v">X_train</span>, <span class="pl-s1">y_train</span>, <span class="pl-v">X_test</span>, <span class="pl-s1">y_test</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-en">titanic_survive</span>()<span class="pl-s1">train_names</span>, <span class="pl-s1">test_names</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-en">titanic_names</span>()<span class="pl-s1">model</span> <span class="pl-s1">max_depth</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-c1">5</span>)<span class="pl-s1">model</span>.<span class="pl-en">fit</span>(<span class="pl-v">X_train</span>, <span class="pl-s1">y_train</span>)<span class="pl-s1">explainer</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-v">ClassifierExplainer</span>(<span class="pl-s1">model</span>, <span class="pl-s1">idxs</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-s1">test_names</span>, <span class="pl-c"># defaults to X.index</span>                                <span class="pl-s1">index_name</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-s">"Passenger"</span>, <span class="pl-c"># defaults to X.index.name</span>                                <span class="pl-s1">target</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-s">"Survival"</span>, <span class="pl-c"># defaults to y.name</span>                                )<span class="pl-s1">db</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-v">ExplainerDashboard</span>(<span class="pl-s1">explainer</span>,                         <span class="pl-s1">title</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-s">"Titanic Explainer"</span>, <span class="pl-c"># defaults to "Model Explainer"</span>                        <span class="pl-s1">shap_interaction</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-c1">False</span>, <span class="pl-c"># you can switch off tabs with bools</span>                        )<span class="pl-s1">db</span>.<span class="pl-en">run</span>(<span class="pl-s1">port</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-c1">8050</span>)</pre></div><p dir="auto">For a regression model you can also pass the units of the target variable (e.g.dollars):</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-python notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="X_train, y_train, X_test, y_test = titanic_fare()model = RandomForestRegressor().fit(X_train, y_train)explainer = RegressionExplainer(model, X_test, y_test,                                 cats=['Deck', 'Embarked', 'Sex'],                                descriptions=feature_descriptions,                                 units = "$", # defaults to ""                                )ExplainerDashboard(explainer).run()"><pre><span class="pl-v">X_train</span>, <span class="pl-s1">y_train</span>, <span class="pl-v">X_test</span>, <span class="pl-s1">y_test</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-en">titanic_fare</span>()<span class="pl-s1">model</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-v">RandomForestRegressor</span>().<span class="pl-en">fit</span>(<span class="pl-v">X_train</span>, <span class="pl-s1">y_train</span>)<span class="pl-s1">explainer</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-v">RegressionExplainer</span>(<span class="pl-s1">model</span>, <span class="pl-v">X_test</span>, <span class="pl-s1">y_test</span>,                                 <span class="pl-s1">cats</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span>[<span class="pl-s">'Deck'</span>, <span class="pl-s">'Embarked'</span>, <span class="pl-s">'Sex'</span>],                                <span class="pl-s1">descriptions</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-s1">feature_descriptions</span>,                                 <span class="pl-s1">units</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-s">"$"</span>, <span class="pl-c"># defaults to ""</span>                                )<span class="pl-v">ExplainerDashboard</span>(<span class="pl-s1">explainer</span>).<span class="pl-en">run</span>()</pre></div><p dir="auto"><code>y_test</code> is actually optional, although some parts of the dashboard like performancemetrics will obviously not be available: <code>ExplainerDashboard(ClassifierExplainer(model, X_test)).run()</code>.</p><p dir="auto">You can export a dashboard to static html with <code>db.save_html('dashboard.html')</code>.</p><details><summary>You can pass a specific index for the static dashboard to display</summary><p dir="auto"></p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="ExplainerDashboard(explainer, index=0).save_html('dashboard.html')"><pre class="notranslate"><code>ExplainerDashboard(explainer, index=0).save_html('dashboard.html')</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">or</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="ExplainerDashboard(explainer, index='Cumings, Mrs. John Bradley (Florence Briggs Thayer)').save_html('dashboard.html')"><pre class="notranslate"><code>ExplainerDashboard(explainer, index='Cumings, Mrs. John Bradley (Florence Briggs Thayer)').save_html('dashboard.html')</code></pre></div><p dir="auto"></p></details><p dir="auto">For a simplified single page dashboard try <code>ExplainerDashboard(explainer, simple=True)</code>.</p><details><summary>Show simplified dashboard screenshot</summary><p dir="auto"></p><p dir="auto"><a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="/oegedijk/explainerdashboard/blob/master/docs/source/screenshots/simple_classifier_dashboard.png"><img src="/oegedijk/explainerdashboard/raw/master/docs/source/screenshots/simple_classifier_dashboard.png" alt="docs/source/screenshots/simple_classifier_dashboard.png" style="max-width: 100%;"></a></p><p dir="auto"></p></details><p dir="auto"></p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">ExplainerHub</h3><a id="user-content-explainerhub" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: ExplainerHub" href="#explainerhub"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">You can combine multiple dashboards and host them in a single place using<a href="https://explainerdashboard.readthedocs.io/en/latest/hub.html" rel="nofollow">ExplainerHub</a>:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-python notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="db1 = ExplainerDashboard(explainer1, title="Classifier Explainer",          description="Model predicting survival on H.M.S. Titanic")db2 = ExplainerDashboard(explainer2, title="Regression Explainer",         description="Model predicting ticket price on H.M.S. Titanic")hub = ExplainerHub([db1, db2])hub.run()"><pre><span class="pl-s1">db1</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-v">ExplainerDashboard</span>(<span class="pl-s1">explainer1</span>, <span class="pl-s1">title</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-s">"Classifier Explainer"</span>,          <span class="pl-s1">description</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-s">"Model predicting survival on H.M.S. Titanic"</span>)<span class="pl-s1">db2</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-v">ExplainerDashboard</span>(<span class="pl-s1">explainer2</span>, <span class="pl-s1">title</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-s">"Regression Explainer"</span>,         <span class="pl-s1">description</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-s">"Model predicting ticket price on H.M.S. Titanic"</span>)<span class="pl-s1">hub</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-v">ExplainerHub</span>([<span class="pl-s1">db1</span>, <span class="pl-s1">db2</span>])<span class="pl-s1">hub</span>.<span class="pl-en">run</span>()</pre></div><p dir="auto">You can adjust titles and descriptions, manage users and logins, store and loadfrom config, manage the hub through a CLI and more. See the<a href="https://explainerdashboard.readthedocs.io/en/latest/hub.html" rel="nofollow">ExplainerHub documentation</a>.</p><details><summary>Show ExplainerHub screenshot</summary><p dir="auto"></p><p dir="auto"><a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="/oegedijk/explainerdashboard/blob/master/docs/source/screenshots/explainerhub.png"><img src="/oegedijk/explainerdashboard/raw/master/docs/source/screenshots/explainerhub.png" alt="docs/source/screenshots/explainerhub.png" style="max-width: 100%;"></a></p><p dir="auto"></p></details><p dir="auto"></p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Dealing with slow calculations</h3><a id="user-content-dealing-with-slow-calculations" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Dealing with slow calculations" href="#dealing-with-slow-calculations"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">Some of the calculations for the dashboard such as calculating SHAP (interaction) valuesand permutation importances can be slow for large datasets and complicated models.There are a few tricks to make this less painful:</p><ol dir="auto"><li>Switching off the interactions tab (<code>shap_interaction=False</code>) and disablingpermutation importances (<code>no_permutations=True</code>). Especially SHAP interactionvalues can be very slow to calculate, and often are not needed for analysis.For permutation importances you can set the <code>n_jobs</code> parameter to speed upthe calculation in parallel.</li><li>Calculate approximate shap values. You can pass approximate=True as a shap parameter bypassing <code>shap_kwargs=dict(approximate=True)</code> to the explainer initialization.</li><li>Storing the explainer. The calculated properties are only calculated oncefor each instance, however each time when you instantiate a new explainerinstance they will have to be recalculated. You can store them with<code>explainer.dump("explainer.joblib")</code> and load with e.g.<code>ClassifierExplainer.from_file("explainer.joblib")</code>. All calculated propertiesare stored along with the explainer.</li><li>Using a smaller (test) dataset, or using smaller decision trees.TreeShap computational complexity is <code>O(TLD^2)</code>, where <code>T</code> is thenumber of trees, <code>L</code> is the maximum number of leaves in any tree and<code>D</code> the maximal depth of any tree. So reducing the number of leaves or averagedepth in the decision tree can really speed up SHAP calculations.</li><li>Pre-computing shap values. Perhaps you already have calculated the shap valuessomewhere, or you can calculate them off on a giant cluster somewhere, oryour model supports <a href="https://github.com/rapidsai/gputreeshap">GPU generated shap values</a>.You can simply add these pre-calculated shap values to the explainerwith <code>explainer.set_shap_values()</code> and <code>explainer.set_shap_interaction_values()</code> methods.</li><li>Plotting only a random sample of points. When you have a lots of observations,simply rendering the plots may get slow as well. You can pass the <code>plot_sample</code>parameter to render a (different each time) random sample of observationsfor the various scatter plots in the dashboard. E.g.:<code>ExplainerDashboard(explainer, plot_sample=1000).run()</code></li></ol><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Launching from within a notebook</h2><a id="user-content-launching-from-within-a-notebook" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Launching from within a notebook" href="#launching-from-within-a-notebook"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">When working inside Jupyter or Google Colab you can use<code>ExplainerDashboard(mode='inline')</code>, <code>ExplainerDashboard(mode='external')</code> or<code>ExplainerDashboard(mode='jupyterlab')</code>, to run the dashboard inline in the notebook,or in a seperate tab but keep the notebook interactive. (<code>db.run(mode='inline')</code>now also works)</p><p dir="auto">There is also a specific interface for quickly displaying interactive componentsinline in your notebook: <code>InlineExplainer()</code>. For example you can use<code>InlineExplainer(explainer).shap.dependence()</code> to display the shap dependencecomponent interactively in your notebook output cell.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Command line tool</h2><a id="user-content-command-line-tool" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Command line tool" href="#command-line-tool"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">You can store explainers to disk with <code>explainer.dump("explainer.joblib")</code>and then run them from the command-line:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ explainerdashboard run explainer.joblib"><pre>$ explainerdashboard run explainer.joblib</pre></div><p dir="auto">Or store the full configuration of a dashboard to <code>.yaml</code> with e.g.<code>dashboard.to_yaml("dashboard.yaml", explainerfile="explainer.joblib", dump_explainer=True)</code> and run it with:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ explainerdashboard run dashboard.yaml"><pre>$ explainerdashboard run dashboard.yaml</pre></div><p dir="auto">You can also build explainers from the commandline with <code>explainerdashboard build</code>.See <a href="https://explainerdashboard.readthedocs.io/en/latest/cli.html" rel="nofollow">explainerdashboard CLI documentation</a>for details.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Customizing your dashboard</h2><a id="user-content-customizing-your-dashboard" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Customizing your dashboard" href="#customizing-your-dashboard"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">The dashboard is highly modular and customizable so that you can adjust it yourown needs and project.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Changing bootstrap theme</h3><a id="user-content-changing-bootstrap-theme" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Changing bootstrap theme" href="#changing-bootstrap-theme"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">You can change the bootstrap theme by passing a link to the appropriate cssfile. You can use the convenient <a href="https://dash-bootstrap-components.opensource.faculty.ai/docs/themes/" rel="nofollow">themes</a> module of<a href="https://dash-bootstrap-components.opensource.faculty.ai/docs/" rel="nofollow">dash_bootstrap_components</a> to generatethe css url for you:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-python notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="import dash_bootstrap_components as dbcExplainerDashboard(explainer, bootstrap=dbc.themes.FLATLY).run()"><pre><span class="pl-k">import</span> <span class="pl-s1">dash_bootstrap_components</span> <span class="pl-k">as</span> <span class="pl-s1">dbc</span><span class="pl-v">ExplainerDashboard</span>(<span class="pl-s1">explainer</span>, <span class="pl-s1">bootstrap</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-s1">dbc</span>.<span class="pl-s1">themes</span>.<span class="pl-v">FLATLY</span>).<span class="pl-en">run</span>()</pre></div><p dir="auto">See the <a href="https://dash-bootstrap-components.opensource.faculty.ai/docs/themes/" rel="nofollow">dbc themes documentation</a>and <a href="https://bootswatch.com/" rel="nofollow">bootwatch website</a> for the different themes that are supported.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Switching off tabs</h3><a id="user-content-switching-off-tabs" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 switch off individual tabs using boolean flags. rel="nofollow">dash</a> dashboardsaround them.</p><p dir="auto">By using the built-in <code>ExplainerComponent</code> class it is easy to build yourown layouts, with just a bare minimum of knowledge of HTML and <a href="https://dash-bootstrap-components.opensource.faculty.ai/docs/quickstart/" rel="nofollow">bootstrap</a>. Forexample if you only wanted to display the <code>ConfusionMatrixComponent</code> and<code>ShapContributionsGraphComponent</code>, but hidea few toggles:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-python notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="from explainerdashboard.custom import *class CustomDashboard(ExplainerComponent):    def __init__(self, explainer, name=None):        super().__init__(explainer, title="Custom Dashboard")        self.confusion = ConfusionMatrixComponent(explainer, name=self.name+"cm",                            hide_selector=True, hide_percentage=True,                            cutoff=0.75)        self.contrib = ShapContributionsGraphComponent(explainer, name=self.name+"contrib",                            hide_selector=True, hide_cats=True,                             hide_depth=True, hide_sort=True,                            index='Rugg, Miss. Emily')            def layout(self):        return dbc.Container([            dbc.Row([                dbc.Col([                    html.H1("Custom Demonstration:"),                    html.H3("How to build your own layout using ExplainerComponents.")                ])            ]),            dbc.Row([                dbc.Col([                    self.confusion.layout(),                ]),                dbc.Col([                    self.contrib.layout(),                ])            ])        ])db = ExplainerDashboard(explainer, CustomDashboard, hide_header=True).run()"><pre><span href="/oegedijk/explainerdashboard/blob/master/docs/source/screenshots/custom_dashboard.png"><img src="/oegedijk/explainerdashboard/raw/master/docs/source/screenshots/custom_dashboard.png" alt="docs/source/screenshots/custom_dashboard.png" style="max-width: 100%;"></a></p><p dir="auto"></p></details><p dir="auto"></p><p dir="auto">You can use this to define your own layouts, specifically tailored to yourown model, project and needs. You can use the <a href="https://github.com/oegedijk/explainerdashboard/blob/master/explainerdashboard/dashboard_components/composites.py">ExplainerComposites</a> thatare used for the tabs of the default dashboard as a starting point, and editthem to reorganize components, add text, etc.See <a href="https://explainerdashboard.readthedocs.io/en/latest/custom.html" rel="nofollow">custom dashboard documentation</a>for more details. A deployed custom dashboard can be found <a href="http://titanicexplainer.herokuapp.com/custom/" rel="nofollow">here</a>(<a href="https://github.com/oegedijk/explainingtitanic/blob/master/buildcustom.py">source code</a>).</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Deployment</h2><a id="user-content-deployment" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Deployment" href="#deployment"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">If you wish to use e.g. <code>gunicorn</code> or <code>waitress</code> to deploy the dashboard you should add<code>app = db.flask_server()</code> to your code to expose the Flask server. You can thenstart the server with e.g. <code>gunicorn dashboard:app</code>(assuming the file you defined the dashboard in was called <code>dashboard.py</code>).See also the <a href="https://explainerdashboard.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dashboards.html" rel="nofollow">ExplainerDashboard section</a>and the <a href="https://explainerdashboard.readthedocs.io/en/latest/deployment.html" rel="nofollow">deployment section of the documentation</a>.</p><p dir="auto">It can be helpful to store your <code>explainer</code> and dashboard layout to disk, andthen reload, e.g.:</p><p dir="auto"><strong>generate_dashboard.py</strong>:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-python notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="from explainerdashboard import ClassifierExplainer, ExplainerDashboardfrom explainerdashboard.custom import *explainer = ClassifierExplainer(model, X_test, y_test)# building an ExplainerDashboard ensures that all necessary properties # get calculated:db = ExplainerDashboard(explainer, [ShapDependenceComposite, WhatIfComposite],                        title='Awesome Dashboard', hide_whatifpdp=True)# store both the explainer and the dashboard configuration:db.to_yaml("dashboard.yaml", explainerfile="explainer.joblib", dump_explainer=True)"><pre><span class="pl-k">from</span> <span class="pl-s1">explainerdashboard</span> <span class="pl-k">import</span> <span class="pl-v">ClassifierExplainer</span>, <span class="pl-v">ExplainerDashboard</span><span class="pl-k">from</span> <span class="pl-s1">explainerdashboard</span>.<span class="pl-s1">custom</span> <span class="pl-k">import</span> <span class="pl-c1">*</span><span class="pl-s1">explainer</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-v">ClassifierExplainer</span>(<span class="pl-s1">model</span>, <span class="pl-v">X_test</span>, <span class="pl-s1">y_test</span>)<span class="pl-c"># building an ExplainerDashboard ensures that all necessary properties </span><span class="pl-c"># get calculated:</span><span class="pl-s1">db</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-v">ExplainerDashboard</span>(<span class="pl-s1">explainer</span>, [<span class="pl-v">ShapDependenceComposite</span>, <span class="pl-v">WhatIfComposite</span>],                        <span class="pl-s1">title</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-s">'Awesome Dashboard'</span>, <span class="pl-s1">hide_whatifpdp</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-c1">True</span>)<span class="pl-c"># store both the explainer and the dashboard configuration:</span><span class="pl-s1">db</span>.<span class="pl-en">to_yaml</span>(<span class="pl-s">"dashboard.yaml"</span>, <span class="pl-s1">explainerfile</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-s">"explainer.joblib"</span>, <span class="pl-s1">dump_explainer</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-c1">True</span>)</pre></div><p dir="auto">You can then reload it in <strong>dashboard.py</strong>:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-python notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="from explainerdashboard import ClassifierExplainer, ExplainerDashboard# you can override params during load from_config:db = ExplainerDashboard.from_config("dashboard.yaml", title="Awesomer Title")app = db.flask_server()"><pre><span class="pl-k">from</span> <span class="pl-s1">explainerdashboard</span> <span class="pl-k">import</span> <span class="pl-v">ClassifierExplainer</span>, <span class="pl-v">ExplainerDashboard</span><span class="pl-c"># you can override params during load from_config:</span><span class="pl-s1">db</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-v">ExplainerDashboard</span>.<span class="pl-en">from_config</span>(<span class="pl-s">"dashboard.yaml"</span>, <span class="pl-s1">title</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-s">"Awesomer Title"</span>)<span class="pl-s1">app</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-s1">db</span>.<span class="pl-en">flask_server</span>()</pre></div><p dir="auto">And then run it with:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="    $ gunicorn dashboard:app"><pre>    $ gunicorn dashboard:app</pre></div><p dir="auto">or with waitress (also works on Windows):</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="    $ waitress-serve dashboard:app"><pre>    $ waitress-serve dashboard:app</pre></div><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Minimizing memory usage</h3><a id="user-content-minimizing-memory-usage" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Minimizing memory usage" href="#minimizing-memory-usage"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">When you deploy a dashboard with a dataset with a large number of rows (<code>n</code>) and columns (<code>m</code>),the memory usage of the dashboard can be substantial. You can check the (approximate)memory usage with <code>explainer.memory_usage()</code>. (as a side note: if you have lotsof rows, you probably want to set the <code>plot_sample</code> parameter as well)</p><p dir="auto">In order to reduce the memory footprint there are a number of things you can do:</p><ol dir="auto"><li><p dir="auto">Not including shap interaction tab: shap interaction values are shape (<code>n*m*m</code>),so can take a subtantial amount of memory.</p></li><li><p dir="auto">Setting a lower precision. By default shap values are stored as <code>'float64'</code>,but you can store them as <code>'float32'</code> instead and save half the space:<code>ClassifierExplainer(model, X_test, y_test, precision='float32')</code>. Youcan also set a lower precision on your <code>X_test</code> dataset yourself of course.</p></li><li><p dir="auto">For multi class classifier, by default <code>ClassifierExplainer</code> calculatesshap values for all classes. If you're only interested in a single classyou can drop the other shap values: <code>explainer.keep_shap_pos_label_only(pos_label)</code></p></li><li><p dir="auto">Storing data externally. You can for example only store a subset of 10.000 rows inthe explainer itself (enough to generate importance and dependence plots),and store the rest of your millions of rows of input data in an external fileor database:</p><ul dir="auto"><li>with <code>explainer.set_X_row_func()</code> you can set a function that takesan <code>index</code> as argument and returns a single row dataframe with modelcompatible input data for that index. This function can include a queryto a database or fileread.</li><li>with <code>explainer.set_y_func()</code> you can set a function that takesand <code>index</code> as argument and returns the observed outcome <code>y</code> forthat index.</li><li>with <code>explainer.set_index_list_func()</code> you can set a functionthat returns a list of available indexes that can be queried. Only getscalled upon start of the dashboard.</li></ul><p dir="auto">If you have a very large number of indexes and the user is able to lookthem up elsewhere, you can also replace the index dropdowns with a simple freetext field with <code>index_dropdown=False</code>. Only valid indexes (i.e. in the<code>get_index_list()</code> list) get propagatedto other components by default, but this can be overriden with <code>index_check=False</code>.Instead of an <code>index_list_func</code> you can also set an<code>explainer.set_index_check_func(func)</code> which should return a bool whetherthe <code>index</code> exists or not.</p><p dir="auto">Important: these function can be called multiple times by multiple independentcomponents, so probably best to implement some kind of caching functionality.The functions you pass can be also methods, so you have access to all of theinternals of the explainer.</p></li></ol><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Documentation</h2><a id="user-content-documentation" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Documentation" href="#documentation"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16"
